quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: States of Matter & Gas Laws
quiz.subtitle: Unit 6, Quiz 1: Fluid Properties and Behavior
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: States of Matter, Fluids, and Gas Laws

questions.question: Which state of matter is characterized by having both a definite shape and a definite volume due to strong intermolecular forces?
questions.explanation: In solids, particles are packed closely together in a fixed structure, preventing them from flowing or expanding to fill a container.

questions.question: In physics, which of the following are classified as 'fluids'?
questions.explanation: Fluids are substances that deform continuously under applied shear stress and have the ability to flow; this includes both liquids and gases.

questions.question: What happens to the viscosity of most liquids as their temperature increases?
questions.explanation: Increased kinetic energy allows liquid molecules to overcome intermolecular forces more easily, reducing the internal friction (resistance to flow).

questions.question: According to Boyle's Law, if the volume of a gas is halved while temperature remains constant, what happens to the pressure?
questions.explanation: Boyle's Law ($P_1V_1 = P_2V_2$) states pressure and volume are inversely proportional. Halving volume doubles the pressure.

questions.question: Which law states that the volume of a gas is directly proportional to its absolute temperature, provided pressure remains constant?
questions.explanation: Charles's Law states that $V/T = k$, meaning volume increases linearly with absolute temperature (Kelvin).

questions.question: Which device is most appropriate for measuring the volume of an irregular solid using the displacement method?
questions.explanation: A graduated cylinder allows you to measure the volume of water displaced by a submerged object, which equals the object's volume.

questions.question: When performing calculations using any of the Gas Laws, which temperature scale must be used?
questions.explanation: The Kelvin scale is an absolute scale starting at absolute zero ($0\text{ K}$), which is necessary for the ratios in gas law equations to be physically valid.

questions.question: Gay-Lussac's Law describes the relationship between which two variables at a constant volume?
questions.explanation: Gay-Lussac's Law ($P/T = k$) states that the pressure of a gas is directly proportional to its absolute temperature when volume is held constant.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a fundamental assumption of the Kinetic Molecular Theory for ideal gases?
options: Gas particles are in constant, random motion
Gas particles exert strong attractive forces on each other
The volume of individual gas particles is negligible
questions.explanation: Ideal gas theory assumes there are no intermolecular forces (attraction or repulsion) between gas particles.

questions.question: A gas occupies 2.0 L at 100 kPa. If the pressure is increased to 400 kPa at constant temperature, what is the new volume?
Which property of a fluid explains why a needle can sometimes float on the surface of water despite being denser than water?
questions.explanation: Surface tension creates a thin 'skin' on the liquid's surface due to cohesive forces between molecules.

questions.question: What is the standard unit of pressure in the SI system?
questions.explanation: The Pascal (Pa) is the SI unit, defined as one Newton per square meter ($1\text{ N/m}^2$).

questions.question: If the absolute temperature of a gas is doubled at a constant pressure, what happens to its volume?
questions.explanation: According to Charles's Law, volume is directly proportional to temperature. Doubling T doubles V.

questions.question: Which state of matter has the highest kinetic energy per particle at a given temperature?
options: They all have exactly the same
questions.explanation: While 'average kinetic energy' defines temperature, gas particles possess the most freedom of motion and highest velocities compared to condensed phases.

questions.question: Which of the following describes 'viscosity'?
options: The mass per unit volume of a fluid
The upward force exerted by a fluid
The internal resistance of a fluid to flow
The ability of a fluid to be compressed
questions.explanation: Viscosity is the measure of a fluid's 'thickness' or its resistance to gradual deformation by shear stress.

questions.question: Using the Combined Gas Law, if pressure, volume, and temperature all change, which formula is used?
questions.explanation: The Combined Gas Law merges Boyle's, Charles's, and Gay-Lussac's laws into one ratio.

questions.question: Why are gases much more compressible than solids or liquids?
options: There is a lot of empty space between gas particles
questions.explanation: In gases, particles are far apart. Applying pressure reduces this empty space, whereas in solids/liquids, particles are already touching.

questions.question: What happens to the pressure of a gas inside a rigid container if the temperature is decreased?
questions.explanation: At constant volume, decreasing temperature reduces the kinetic energy and frequency of particle collisions with the walls, lowering pressure.

questions.question: A sample of gas occupies 10 L at 200 K. What is its volume at 400 K if pressure is constant?
questions.explanation: $V_1/T_1 = V_2/T_2 \rightarrow 10/200 = V_2/400 \rightarrow V_2 = 20\text{ L}$.

questions.question: When reading the volume of water in a glass graduated cylinder, you should read from:
options: The average of the top and bottom
questions.explanation: For liquids like water that wet the glass, the meniscus is concave; accuracy requires reading from the lowest point of the curve at eye level.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a firm grasp of fluid properties and gas behaviors.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Review the specific mathematical relationships in the Gas Laws.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Spend more time studying the Kinetic Molecular Theory and unit conversions.
